name: NPR
text: The polio experience differed from today's COVID-19 in one important respect: by the 1950s, polio ‚Äî a disabling and potentially deadly disease -- was a familiar threat. Even former President Franklin D. Roosevelt had been stricken with the disease. https://t.co/F4IAya0aT1

name: NPR
text:
Many people with disabilities and elderly people who have difficulty communicating rely on family members or a direct service professional to help them get medical care. Now, many of those family members are being kept away. 
https://t.co/NjpABfhu5F

name: NPR
text: Lyndsay Tucker, a 25-year-old skin care consultant, had never heard of Elon Musk until a couple years ago, when she began fielding a steady stream of calls and text messages intended for the Tesla and SpaceX founder and CEO. https://t.co/uyhJPY7dbj

name: NPR
text: Unlike its Nordic neighbors, Sweden decided against instituting a strict lockdown. The government has enforced social distancing rules, but decided to keep most bars, restaurants, schools and retail shops open. https://t.co/aWnIo0QcWy

name: NPR
text:
A ruling on Sunday by a U.S. District Court judge has moved hundreds of thousands of felons who have completed "all terms of their sentence including probation and parole" one step closer to winning back their right to vote. 
https://t.co/r00pU1XkDY

name: NPR
text: Works Progress Administration funding redefined America's shared culture and probably saved an acclaimed generation of artists. But arts leaders say reviving the program today is probably wishful thinking. https://t.co/KqANb1oWVK

name: NPR
text:
Across the U.S. the effort to prevent infection in older people, who are most at risk of serious COVID-19 illness, has meant self-imposed exile for many. Others, meanwhile, have taken over daily child care duties to help adult children who must work.
https://t.co/gpqkDKJOxm

name: NPR
text: When Clem Snide and special guest Scott Avett performed together in Avett's barn, they added a few features you've never gotten to hear at the Tiny Desk ‚Äî most notably a noisy flock of birds and the unmistakable cries of a nearby rooster. https://t.co/AzS0RsJQRJ

name: NPR
text: The coronavirus has not spared the U.S. prison at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, where legal proceedings have come to a virtual standstill due to the pandemic. That has critics of Guant√°namo saying this is a chance to shut it down for good. https://t.co/Wod0bhefgk

name: NPR
text:
In communities across the country, families are dealing with more than just the threat of the coronavirus outside their homes. Amid violence that does not stop even during a pandemic, children continually search for safety, peace and a quiet place. 
https://t.co/KSTqdRVNhq

name: NPR
text:
The 2020 presidential election was on track to see a huge surge in new voters, far outpacing the registration in 2016.  

But as the pandemic shut down the country, voter registration flatlined ‚Äî which could reshape how the electorate looks in November. https://t.co/ONVhQIwpZe

name: NPR
text:
Federal records show OSHA worked for six years to create new rules to prepare for an airborne infectious disease pandemic. The Obama White House formally added it to a list of regulations to be implemented in 2017.

Then President Trump took office. https://t.co/D0KJ2HInzt

name: NPR
text:
A new state-wide program to get financial help for the nearly 2 million illegal immigrants in California was nearly overwhelmed by the demand within its first week.

But there's only enough aid for 250,000, leaving 1.75 million without assistance. https://t.co/MlV6iluGRR

name: NPR
text:
Timothy Regan was told by a nurse hotline that he should go get tested for COVID-19 at an urgent care. The doctors didn't test him, but told him to act as if he was infected and quarantine himself. 

Then, weeks later, the $3,278 bill came. 
https://t.co/rtCrKHMmk9

name: NPR
text:
NASA and SpaceX are launching the first American spacecraft from American soil in almost nine years on Wednesday. 

Some experts think this historic launch could be the start of a revolution for space travel ‚Äî including putting Tom Cruise in space. https://t.co/i47LCTVnP6

name: NPR
text: Four Minneapolis Police Department officers have been fired after the death of George Floyd, who was seen in a video repeatedly crying out ‚ÄúI cannot breath‚Äù as an officer kneeled on his neck.   https://t.co/SZ2usBQkum

name: NPR
text:
Almost half of the COVID-19 cases in Montgomery County, Alabama, were confirmed in the last 14 days. 

Montgomery Mayor Steven Reed says one problem is people who "have decided that the pandemic is over." 
https://t.co/SAcCLic1uO

name: NPR
text:
What's better than hearing artists we love covering songs they love? 

For the newest edition of @allsongs, we follow some much-loved voices singing hits by other bands. Listen here üéß https://t.co/rVpGHqGMoW

name: NPR
text:
For the first time, Twitter has put a fact-checking warning on a tweet from President Trump because it contains "misleading information about the voting process," a company spokesman says.
https://t.co/kytfodn7MC

name: NPR
text:
NEW: More than 20 Republicans will sue House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other officials in federal court to block proxy voting, arguing it is unconstitutional, according to two GOP leadership sources and an attorney on the case.
https://t.co/Ej6Ogn46Gd
